description: From Middle English britel, brutel, brotel (“brittle”), from Old English *brytel, *bryttol (“brittle, fragile”, literally “prone to or tending to break”); equivalent to brit +‎ -le.

adjectives.description: brittle (comparative brittler or more brittle, superlative brittlest or most brittle)

entries.meaning: Inflexible; liable to break, snap, or shatter easily under stress, pressure, or impact.
examples: Cast iron is much more brittle than forged iron.
A diamond is hard but brittle.

entries.meaning: Not physically tough or tenacious; apt to break or crumble when bending.
examples: Shortbread is my favorite cold pastry, yet being so brittle it crumbles easily, and a lot goes to waste.

entries.meaning: (archaeology) Said of rocks and minerals with a conchoidal fracture; capable of being knapped or flaked.

examples: What a brittle personality! A little misunderstanding and he's an emotional wreck.

entries.meaning: (engineering, computing, of a system) Poorly error- or fault-tolerant; having little in the way of redundancy or defense in depth; susceptible to catastrophic failure in the event of a relatively-minor malfunction or deviance.
(informal, proscribed) Diabetes that is characterized by dramatic swings in blood sugar level.
A confection of caramelized sugar and nuts.
examples: As a child, my favorite candy was peanut brittle.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Anything resembling this confection, such as flapjack, a cereal bar, etc.

verbs.description: brittle (third-person singular simple present brittles, present participle brittling, simple past and past participle brittled)

examples: The project is based on a similar project, the Class project, which was started by the University of Cornell several years ago under the leadership of Stuart Lynn to preserve brittling old books.
